head.title: Return to Sender, But Only if You Can

hedline.hl1: Return to Sender, But Only if You Can

block.p: Re ''Now That I Have Your Attention'' (Backslash, Oct. 8), in which Matt Richtel described his frustrating quest to find information about spammers -- the senders of unsolicited commercial e-mail messages:

Re ''Now That I Have Your Attention'' (Backslash, Oct. 8), in which Matt Richtel described his frustrating quest to find information about spammers -- the senders of unsolicited commercial e-mail messages:
In the column, a provider of bulk e-mail software said that when someone uses the program to send unsolicited mail, the messages should include a way to decline future overtures.
I have received several e-mail messages over the last few weeks that appear to get around that idea in one of two ways.

The simplest is for the sender to claim that the message is part of a ''one-time mailing''; the second is to instruct the recipient to send an e-mail response to a listed address and to write ''Remove'' in the subject line.

The difficulty in dealing with the second approach, as you might expect, is that I have never been able to return messages to the ''removal'' address. Usually, I receive an error message that the user is unknown.
I would rather receive a straightforward message that I can delete than one that encourages me to waste more of my time sending and receiving more mail.
